data.title: Review: Gunpowder and Geometry: The Life of Charles Hutton, Pit Boy, Mathematician and Scientific Rebel by Benjamin Wardhaugh — a meticulous yet lively biography
data.meta_description: Think of famous mathematicians and Charles Hutton probably isn’t high on your list. data.text:
Think of famous mathematicians and Charles Hutton probably isn’t high on your list. In the 18th century, however, he was a household name, famous for his ground-breaking work on ballistics and for estimating the density of the Earth. How did this pit boy, born in Newcastle’s coal country in 1737, become the “darling of the Royal Society” in London?

This engaging biography reveals a self-made man of remarkable drive. He had brains, of course, but just as impressive were his work ethic and aptitude for social climbing. He rose rapidly from village teacher, to tutor and textbook author, to professor at the Royal Military Academy in Woolwich — helped, rumour had it, by calling in a favour from the patron of his book, the Duke
